image.altText: Aerial photo of flooding.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of people were rescued overnight, with several still stranded as heavy rainfall and dangerous flash flooding continues in Far North Queensland.

title.children: Authorities scrambling to evacuate flooded Wujal Wujal, Cairns Airport runway cleared after break in rainfall

image.altText: Damage from major flooding in Ellis Beach.

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology says heavy rainfall is expected to continue for already-waterlogged areas of Queensland's Far North for most of today. Follow live.

title.children: Defence force deployed to Far North Queensland as Cairns mayor warns of 'critical' water shortage

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: ADF choppers flying in to assist
Supermarkets packed as residents stock up on supplies

image.altText: Houses under construction in the background with building materials in the foreground

props.synopsis: South Australia's transport minister says the cost of finishing infrastructure at an abandoned housing development in Adelaide's south will cost nearly $3.5 million — three times initial predictions.

title.children: Cost of finishing infrastructure at Felmeri Homes development triples, SA government says

image.altText: Woman in purple dress sitting on seat outside house with stone featuring patting cream coloured dog, doghouse in left corner.

props.synopsis: South Australia ranks worst in the country in a national tradie shortage that's keeping critical state housing empty, as vulnerable people face a bleak Christmas with no home to call their own.

title.children: Ally is at the top of the rental list in a town with 48 empty social houses, but she could be waiting three more years

image.altText: A giant orange sphere with stairs leading into it.

props.synopsis: It has been decades since the Big Orange in South Australia's Riverland was worth a visit, but a $1.5 million transformation is set to make it a bar, restaurant and distillery.

title.children: Major overhaul for The Big Orange unveiled after 20 years of sitting dormant

image.altText: A police car outside National Zoo and Aquarium.

props.synopsis: ACT police and emergency services were called to the Canberra zoo about 12:50pm today after reports of a disturbance, where they found the woman dead in a commercial kitchen area.

title.children: Woman found dead at National Zoo and Aquarium, person of interest in police custody

image.altText: Close up of Brittany Higgins.

props.synopsis: Fiona Brown, who was chief of staff for Senator Linda Reynolds at the time of Brittany Higgins's alleged rape, has been allowed to give evidence in a closed session as part of the defamation trial brought by Bruce Lehrmann against Network Ten and Lisa Wilkinson, due to the potential for adverse effects on her mental health.

title.children: Brittany Higgins's former chief of staff Fiona Brown allowed to give evidence in closed court session

image.altText: Ella holding a toy that belonged to Jesse when he was little.

props.synopsis: Parents with violent children can face a heartbreaking decision: give them up or continue to live in danger. Experts say more needs to be done to help families facing complex situations.

title.children: 'The fear is that Jesse will kill me one day': This mother faces a heartbreaking decision to relinquish care

image.altText: The Matildas celebrate in Melbourne

props.synopsis: A first Olympic medal is on the radar for the Matildas, who will face Uzbekistan in Melbourne on February 28 to decide which nation qualifies for Paris.

title.children: Melbourne-bound Matildas have Olympic medal firmly in their sights

image.altText: An elderly caucasian in a blue suit, red tie, speaking into a microphone with an American flag in the background.

props.synopsis: Speaking at a rally in Nevada, Donald Trump also calls US President Joe Biden a "low-IQ individual" and the "worst, most incompetent and most corrupt president" in the history of the United States.

title.children: Trump promises 'largest deportation operation in American history' if elected

image.altText: Christopher Luxon in parliament, pointing and looking quite cross.

props.synopsis: In three weeks, New Zealand's new prime minister has moved to wind back policies designed to improve outcomes for Māori and Pasifika people, and people are taking to the streets.

title.children: 'It's an absolute disgrace': In three weeks, NZ's new PM has reignited race relations

image.altText: Papua New Guinea police officers watch on as hundreds of students marched towards the university gate in Port Moresby

props.synopsis: Chiefs and community leaders in Bougainville want an investigation into police officers over their alleged involvement in arming and orchestrating an organised crime gang that targeted people who had travelled to the autonomous region to buy guns and gold.

title.children: In Bougainville, the 'wanted boys' are known for robbing cashed-up visitors. Police are allegedly orchestrating it

image.altText: Singer Jimmy Barnes smiling with his wife asfter surgery

props.synopsis: The 67-year-old enjoys some fresh air and a family lunch after having open-heart surgery to address a bacterial infection last week.

title.children: Jimmy Barnes all smiles during first Sunday roast since open-heart surgery

image.altText: The Queensland cabinet appointed by new premier Steven Miles on the steps of Government House

props.synopsis: Days after he became premier, Steven Miles's first cabinet has been sworn in today with five fresh faces joining the frontbench and three Palaszczuk ministers heading to the backbench. Follow live.

title.children: Steven Miles reshuffles Queensland cabinet with fresh faces and no dedicated Olympics portfolio

image.altText: Farmer's hand feels ripe yellow barley

props.synopsis: The improvement in the results is mostly due to increased livestock prices and solid grain yields across the state, Rabobank says.

title.children: Rain gives SA farmers confidence boost as they head into new year

image.altText: Sign in Hebrew in red food

props.synopsis: Israel's military says it found the signs, made from leftover food, in a building near where the incident happened, as the families of the dead lay blame.

title.children: Israel's military says hostages killed by IDF made SOS signs

image.altText: A small cylindrical black speak-like object sits on a kitchen counter top.

props.synopsis: Researchers are investigating whether Amazon's Alexa, Apple's Siri or Google Home speakers should be used to detect violence in homes.

title.children: How smart speakers 'could detect domestic violence'

image.altText: Flooded world showing a Ferris Wheel and a woman in a small boat.

props.synopsis: Video games had a bumper 2023, but the Australian games industry is suffering through one of its worst contractions since the global financial crisis, with lay-offs and studio closures predicted to continue across 2024. What's going on?

title.children: 'Survive until 25': Australian video game studios brace for grim year ahead

image.altText: A person checks their phone while sitting on brick steps while wearing ripped jeans.

props.synopsis: Almost everything you say, do, or see online travels the globe under the sea through a network of cables that connect almost every country on the planet — but it's also susceptible to espionage.

title.children: We all rely on the world wide web under the waves — but who's watching who?

image.altText: A hand holding a $100 note next to a wallet

props.synopsis: Australia's inflation struggle and cost-of-living crisis will be front and centre as 2023 ends and a new one begins, keeping the Reserve Bank back in the national economic driver's seat for another year, writes David Taylor.

title.children: Australia's economic crisis will be front and centre as 2023 ends. But will 2024 be more prosperous?

image.altText: A woman wearing a striped shirt and pink blouse looking serious with hands clasped in front of a metal bench and tree

props.synopsis: More than nine months on from the unexpected axing of a local TV news bulletin, an outback mayor says it's a major loss for regional news diversity and intends to continue advocating for its return.

title.children: Remote towns say axing of nightly news bulletin has 'added to isolation'

image.altText: Two women wear traditional Hazara headscarves and clothing.

props.synopsis: Hazara women Zahra Anvari and Gol Nazari settled in Tasmania as refugees seven years ago after decades of persecution. But after a violent incident, the day-to-day fear of discrimination continues.

title.children: Attackers try to rip headscarfs from Hobart mother and daughter

image.altText: Darren Chalmers wearing a grey tracksuit being escorted into court by police.

props.synopsis: Darren Chalmers has received a second life sentence for the murder of Geelong woman Annette Steward in 1992, after he killed WA woman Dianne Barrett in 2019.

title.children: Annette Steward's murder remained a mystery for 27 years. Her killer is likely to spend the rest of his life in prison

image.altText: An object is handed to a police officer from a police diver searching the seabed along the Tweed River.

props.synopsis: The father of the nine-month-old tried to give the baby girl to a homeless woman the day of her death, while case workers say they were unaware of mental health and alcohol-related issues during a meeting, an inquest hears.

title.children: Child protective services worker reported no safety concerns weeks before baby was drowned by father

image.altText: hands typing on a laptop

props.synopsis: The new breed of investment and share trading apps targeting retail investors and self-managed super funds are convenient for some but a headache for others, including the corporate regulator, which has found mis-selling, mislabelling, and misleading disclosures, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: A million clients, almost $900b and high-risk assets: The trading wild west on ASIC's radar

image.altText: A woman smiles.

props.synopsis: The Australian Retailers Association estimates South Australians will spend $4.3 billion this Christmas, defying a national downward trend, but businesses say consumers are being thrifty with their shopping.

title.children: South Australians estimated to defy national spending trend ahead of Christmas

image.altText: Bushfire burns orange and red on the horizon at night against the silhouette of a windmill, as stars twinkle above in a dark sky

props.synopsis: A bushfire in the Pilliga State Forest near Narrabri is threatening lives and properties in Bohena Creek between McCanns Road, Perimeter Road, Tomlinson Lane and the Newell Highway.

title.children: Residents told to seek shelter as NSW bushfire spanning 64,000 hectares upgraded to emergency level

image.altText: The exterior of the court, showing the sign and the crest.

props.synopsis: The man allegedly sexually assaulted the teenage girl in the stairwell of a popular Canberra nightclub before allegedly raping her outside in a laneway.

title.children: Irish man accused of raping 16-year-old in Canberra arrested while preparing to leave Australia

image.altText: A man, surrounded by poice and supporters, enters a prison van, wearing a suit and face mask

props.synopsis: A landmark national security trial begins in Hong Kong for prominent activist publisher Jimmy Lai, who faces a possible life sentence if convicted under a law imposed by Beijing to crush dissidents.

title.children: Historic trial against Hong Kong media tycoon charged under national security law begins

image.altText: Scott Boland appeals

props.synopsis: Australia's easy win over Pakistan in the first Test is set to deny cult hero Scott Boland a shot at repeating his famous Boxing Day heroics.

title.children: No MCG repeat for Scott Boland as Australia plan for unchanged side in Boxing Day Test

image.altText: A woman in a wheelchair poses smiling with a long lens camera around her neck.

props.synopsis: Self-titled 'music photographer on wheels' Brittany Long says she doesn't let her wheelchair stop her from getting the best possible shot at live gigs. "I'm known for doing whatever it takes".

title.children: 'I'm known for doing whatever it takes': A day in the life of a music photographer on wheels

image.altText: Pink lake

props.synopsis: A warmer, drier climate could mean more salt lakes in Western Australia will turn pink, but less rainfall could also dry up some lakes entirely.

title.children: They look spectacular and tourists love them, but are Australia's pink lakes a sign of climate change?

image.altText: A group of leaders holding hands.

props.synopsis: Next March, leaders from across South-East Asia will join a major summit in Melbourne to celebrate the 50th anniversary of ties between Australia and ASEAN. What is the meeting all about, and what are the trickiest issues the leaders will grapple with?

title.children: ASEAN country leaders will land in Melbourne for a major summit. Here's why it's so important to Australia

image.altText: Prawns

props.synopsis: Floods and storms had fishermen biting their nails in October. Now, they are counting their blessings as eastern king prawns make an early appearance.

title.children: Early arrival of prawns a Christmas gift for communities that have been through storms, floods and fires

image.altText: A woman smiling in front of a large stature of a rainbow trout

props.synopsis: Built in 1973 by late Hungarian artist Andrew Lomnici, the iconic statue in Adaminaby, in the NSW Snowy Mountains, has recently undergone extensive repairs.

title.children: Big Trout gets makeover in its 50th year as Australia's obsession with 'big things' continues
